description: From Latin fabricātus, perfect passive participle of fabricor, fabricō (“build, forge”), from fabrica (“a fabric, building, etc.”); see fabric and forge. Compare with French fabrique.

verbs.description: fabricate (third-person singular simple present fabricates, present participle fabricating, simple past and past participle fabricated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form into a whole by uniting its parts; to construct; to build.
examples: to fabricate a bridge or ship

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form by art and labor; to manufacture; to produce.
(transitive) To invent and form; to forge; to devise falsely.
examples: to fabricate a lie or story

entries.meaning: (transitive, cooking) To cut up an animal as preparation for cooking, particularly used in reference to fowl.
